title: raspberry gpio open value permission denied bad behavior
body:
hello,
while using the raspi adapter, there seems to be a problem how `LedDriver`'s `On()`/`Off()` behaves in an error case.

minimal code for reproduction on a raspberry pi:

```go
package main

import (
	"log"

	"gobot.io/x/gobot/drivers/gpio"
	"gobot.io/x/gobot/platforms/raspi"
)

const pinBCM18 = "12"

func main() {
	adp := raspi.NewAdaptor()
	led := gpio.NewLedDriver(adp, pinBCM18)

	for i := 0; i < 3; i++ {
		if err := led.On(); err != nil {
			log.Println(err)
		} else {
			log.Println("success - start program again")
			break
		}
	}

	adp.Finalize()
}
```

when this program is run, in ~ 1/10 of cases, the opening of the pin's value is failing with "permission denied".

that is the line failing: https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/blob/ea371766fb4c8d84feeeb9e164bc664786896432/sysfs/digital_pin.go#L124

this is how the output of the program looks:
```
2020/04/17 17:26:20 open /sys/class/gpio/gpio18/value: permission denied
2020/04/17 17:26:20 pin has not been exported
2020/04/17 17:26:20 pin has not been exported
```

there are now two issues:
1. why is opening `/value` sometimes failing, but most of the time it's not and how to fix this? this only happens if the pin was not exported before the program was run.
2. when `On()`/`Off()` is tried again, it surrenders making the pin available and the error changes, making some retry mechanism implementation impossible. probably caused by this (there is also a comment about some potential issue with the current implementation): https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/blob/ea371766fb4c8d84feeeb9e164bc664786896432/sysfs/digital_pin.go#L128-L130

title: Allow capture of values written to gpioTestAdapter for asserting in tests
body:
As I started working on the changes for #742 I wanted to be able to verify the values written via `DigitalWrite` in the unit tests for `RelayDriver`.

To do this I had to align the function signatures in `gpioTestAdaptor`.

For example, this is the `DigitalWrite` signature:

```go
func (t *gpioTestAdaptor) DigitalWrite(pin string, val byte) (err error) 
```

But the function that can be injected to control the behaviour of the test adapter has this signature:

```go
func() (err error) 
```

This core of this PR is to change the signature of the injected function to align with the `DigitalWrite` Signature:

```go
func(pin string, val byte) (err error)
```

The same change has been made for the other functions in `gpioTestAdapter`.

Most of the rest of the changes in the PR are updating code so that it still compiles with these changes, but there are a couple of tests for `RelayDriver` that have been updated to supply a function that captures the value written via `DigitalWrite` so that the test can assert that it is the expected value.

title: Update value written via DigitalWrite if RelayDriver.Inverted is true
body:
The goal of this PR is to update the RelayDriver to write `0` instead of `1` for `On()` if `Inverted` has been set `true` (and similar inversion for `Off()`, as per [this comment](https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/issues/648#issuecomment-605701451) and [initial agreement](https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/issues/648#issuecomment-605701691) from @deadprogram 

I ended up making more changes in this PR than I initially expected, but they are broken into three separate commits if that helps:

* Update `gpioTestAdapter` so that the signatures of functions to provide behaviour match the `DigitalWriter` interface methods etc. This paves the way for capturing the values that are written
* Update the `RelayDriver` tests to capture and validate the values that are written via `DigitalWrite`
* Update the RelayDriver to write `0` instead of `1` for `On()` if `Inverted` has been set `true` (and similar inversion for `Off()`

Apologies for the extra changes - I wanted to ensure that there were tests for this change. If there's an alternate way to perform these tests that you'd prefer then let me know.

I believe that this closes #648

title: Update gobot leap platform to support Leap Motion API v6
body:
This pull request updates the leap platform module from Leap Motion REST API v3 to v6. The changes to the code are rather small, but the additional information from the Leap Motion with the new API is substantial. This is my first go code, but I tried to match idiosyncracies and style.

This change does include 3 breaking changes. In Gesture, Hands is now HandIDs, and Pointables is now PointableIDs. In InteractionBox, center is now an array of float64 (as per the API spec) instead of int. No breaking changes were made to Pointable or Hand (only additional fields). I suspect most users of the Leap Motion API were not using the fields in question, but if so they'll have to update their code.

New features include the ability to get the arm position vectors, the finger bone positions, the finger type (thumb, etc), the finger size, as well as additional details about gestures.

title: Automation model
body:
## What
An evolution in the way Gobot manages automation, this PR introduces the concept of `RobotWork`, managed in a `RobotWorkRegistry`. This construct exists on the `Robot` type and is accessed by new `Every` and `After` methods implemented directly on a `Robot`. 

In contrast to the existing `Every` and `After` functions, these `Robot` methods take a `context.Context` as well as a duration and a function. Calling `Robot.Every()` and `Robot.After()` will create new `RobotWork` instances, place them in a goroutine-safe registry, and set up a cancellable context.

## Why
This allows us to extend the semantics of automation in Gobot by placing the responsibility for managing discreet work unit on the `Robot` itself, along side attendant `Driver` and `Connection` types, making for easier extension of these related concerns later.
* Repeating or future-scheduled workloads can be cancelled externally and synchronized together
* `Robot.Every` tracks successful iterations of each work function with a monotonic counter
* Using `context.Context` allows for the usage of powerful patterns in orchestrating work units

## Caveats/Questions
* I *think* I've got the goroutine-safety stuff covered, but would like a bit more eyes on them
* Have I missed any tests?

**Summary:**

I think to correctly use pi-blaster on raspberry pi, SetPeriod() in platforms/raspi/pwm_pin.go should be allowed to change the now-constant value of piBlasterPeriod. 

**Details:**

**Example:**

For example, my CYCLE_TIME_US is set to 20000us (which is 20000000ns, currently it's fixed to 10000000). To set 1.5ms PWM signal the correct command to write to `/dev/pi-blaster` is `18=0.075`.  (where 18 is the pin 12). However, the following code

```
pin.SetDutyCycle(1.5 * 1000 * 1000)
```
will write `18=0.15`.

title: Initial support for MAX7219 & MAX7221 led drivers
body:
** Read before merging **
This is the driver for MAX 7219 / 7221 LED drivers, but I was only able to test it with MAX 7219 (don't have any 7221), but it's supposed to work with it too.

The official datasheets mentions that only the MAX7221 supports SPI (not the 7219), but most of the libraries available for Arduino use a mix of SPI and direct control of the SS/CS pin. I opted for direct control of pins instead of SPI because it's more versatile (works on TCPFirmata for example), but the speed might be slower than using SPI.

At this point, I'm not sure if I should rename the driver to max7219 only and make a SPI one for max7221, make a spi for both of them in replacement of this or make a spi driver in addition to this, so you will be able to use whatever suits you better (gpio or spi). I think this is fine for most cases.


Additionally, the driver is pretty simple as it's usually sold separately and the led arrangement (if in a matrix) is not always the same (it doesn't even has to be a matrix, it could be a 7-segment display).

Fixes #454

## What
This PR moves dependency management out of a manually maintained list in the `Makefile` and into dep artifacts (see issue #454). It also moves CI checks from in-lined bash in `.travis.yml` into `Makefile` targets and ensures that tests will exclude code in the `vendor/` directory. It also implements a variety of other build fixes and opinions as detailed below.

## Why
This will make development easier, less error-prone, and enable some dependency re-factoring that I've wanted to do for awhile. More broadly, the changes in this PR ensures that tests are run **the same way** in both development and CI.

## What Else
A number of improvements / alterations to the build process:

* `.travis.yml` now delegates everything to tasks defined in `Makefile`
* `Makefile`'s targets delegate to shell scripts in `ci/` dir where necessary
* Formatting check will fail the build if `gofmt -l` returns any files and print the problem paths

title: Fixed raspi adaptor race conditions
body:
(my first PR for this repo, I hope I did everything right. Since it is an hotfix, I'm pulling into the master :crossed_fingers:)

# TL;DR

Since raspi adaptor is accessed concurrently, it must be thread safe

# The problem

I'm developing a Raspberry 3 project that uses Gobot to read from digital input pins. 
This project uses many concurrent goroutines, so I set `runtime.GOMAXPROCS(4)`.
When I ran it sometimes I got: 

```
fatal error: concurrent map writes

goroutine 38 [running]:
runtime.throw(0x39b4e9, 0x15)
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/panic.go:596 +0x70 fp=0x108f3ecc sp=0x108f3ec0
runtime.mapassign(0x353d08, 0x108117c0, 0x108f3f3c, 0x0)
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/hashmap.go:589 +0x274 fp=0x108f3f1c sp=0x108f3ecc
gobot.io/x/gobot/platforms/raspi.(*Adaptor).digitalPin(0x1084e940, 0x108afa68, 0x2, 0x395a07, 0x2, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
	/home/pi/go/src/gobot.io/x/gobot/platforms/raspi/raspi_adaptor.go:136 +0x1c0 fp=0x108f3f4c sp=0x108f3f1c
gobot.io/x/gobot/platforms/raspi.(*Adaptor).DigitalRead(0x1084e940, 0x108afa68, 0x2, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
	/home/pi/go/src/gobot.io/x/gobot/platforms/raspi/raspi_adaptor.go:151 +0x3c fp=0x108f3f74 sp=0x108f3f4c
gobot.io/x/gobot/drivers/gpio.(*ButtonDriver).Start.func1(0x10816510, 0x10904430)
	/home/pi/go/src/gobot.io/x/gobot/drivers/gpio/button_driver.go:57 +0x38 fp=0x108f3fe4 sp=0x108f3f74
runtime.goexit()
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/asm_arm.s:1017 +0x4 fp=0x108f3fe4 sp=0x108f3fe4
created by gobot.io/x/gobot/drivers/gpio.(*ButtonDriver).Start
	/home/pi/go/src/gobot.io/x/gobot/drivers/gpio/button_driver.go:70 +0x48
	
[... cut ...]
```

# The cause

When a `robot.Start()` is called, it starts the ButtonDrivers in a cycle. `buttonDriver.Start()` creates a goroutine that polls its pin; this way we have N concurrent accesses to the adaptor.
Raspi adaptor generates the pins in a lazy way, using a map to keep the references to the created ones.
Go panics when detects that a map is accessed concurrently (worse: it panics and exits the program and cannot be recovered)

# The solution

We have to properly synchronize the adaptor to avoid those kind of issues. Looking at the source code, we can found similar problems for pwmPins and i2cBuses (both backed by an array).
I added a couple of tests to verify two package internal functions. I know that many people dislike this white-box approach, but in this case the correctness is more important :) Please note that `TestAdaptor_concurrentDigitalPin` fails in a brutal way, since we cannot recover from a concurrent access to a map.
After that I added a `*sync.Mutex` to `Adaptor` that is used to protect the critical sections of every mutable variable, `name` included, to respect the memory model of the language.
I also refactored a bit the functions to make the code clearer and simpler.
When I had to choose between performance and safety, I preferred the latter thinking about the typical use case for this component: usually its component are accessed at the startup with low contention, so the mutex overhead is really negligible.

title: Feature/pwm period
body:
Hello,

I've been trying to use servos with Gobot on the Raspberry Pi, and I think it's currently a bit too limited to support all cases. I'm proposing this change to offer better support. The improvements are:
* Support for custom angle range (you can say that you servo can go from -140 to +150 degrees)
* Support for custom PWM timings, as servos are not using the same periods for the signal.
* Added interface to set the PWM signal period in seconds which removes the need for a ServoWriter interface. It means that any platform which supports PWM supports servos, with less code.
* That change also improves the precision of the positioning, as described in issue #287 

The last point is a breaking change, and currently only works on Raspberry Pi - I don't know the other platforms. You have to consider that this is a work in progress.

The creation of a new instance would be like that:
`servo := gpio.NewAngularServoDriver(r, "40", gpio.WithServoAngles(-80.0, 80.0), gpio.WithPeriodRange(0.7/1000.0, 2.3/1000.0))`
With the gpio.WithServoAngles and gpio.WithPeriodRange being optional, defaulting to current values in the servo implementation.

And the interface to move the servo remains unchanged (except that angles are float):
`servo.Move(45.8)`

What do you think? Do you think it could be a good change for Gobot?

title: Significantly speed up travis and make runs

- Inline ci/travis.sh into .travis.yml

I experimented a bit on travis with go test on another similar project, timings
for the go test step only:
- Using both -race and -coverprofile with the loop over $(go list ./...) took
  190s
- Using -coverprofile alone with the loop over $(go list ./...) took 10~11s
- Using -race ./... took 5s

It means that using one after the other takes 16~17s while running with both
flags takes 190s. A 91% speedup. Add my previous commit that cut off the test
runtime by half, the total speed will be appreciable.

title: Change to make I2C support more than one bus and other access methods than "block"
body:
Hi there!

These are my suggested changes to the I2C interface.

Based on the changes discussed in https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/issues/247,
I started out with @abourget's changes to sysfs, and added a new layer in drivers/i2c
to support multiple buses.

The old interface is kept in parallel, I've only implemented the required platform
changes in the c.h.i.p adaptor.

For adaptors, there is a new interface, which replaces the I2c interface: 

```
type I2cConnector interface {
	I2cGetConnection(address int, bus int) (device I2cConnection, err error)
}
```

Driver implementations will then use this interface to get a connection to a
device at a given address + bus combination.

I've also added more fine grained I2C methods than just block read / write,
which simplifies driver implementation.

See https://github.com/erkkah/gobot/blob/tsl2561-driver/drivers/i2c/tsl2561_driver.go
for a driver example using the new interface.

Furthermore this is the first time I'm working with Gobot and the GoPiGo platform, so if some of the decisions I make seem totally bonkers feel free to correct me.  

The implementation is based of the Python and C implementation from [Dexter Industries](https://github.com/DexterInd/GoPiGo/tree/master/Software).

Some questions regarding the design:

The `NewGoPiPoAdaptor` returns an error because it starts the I2C communication between the Rasberry Pi and the GoPiGo board. Can it stay this way or should the start call to I2C be moved into its own method?  

At the moment the commands to control the robot are tied to the platform. Should this be moved 
into one or multiple drivers?

I implemented the `DigitalRead` Method as an example for the Gobot interface. The pin gets translated with the help of the `pins` map. The pin numbers are limited because of the way its done in the [Python implementation](https://github.com/DexterInd/GoPiGo/blob/master/Software/Python/gopigo.py#L298).
And returns `erros.New("no such pin")` if a wrong pin number is provided.
@DexterInd can you tell me why it's limited this way in the read methods but in the wirte methods its commented out?  

The I2C communication uses it's own buffer for every call. I could use one global buffer to reduce 
the GC noise but then I would need to take care of concurrent API calls? 

The next question is about how much work should be offloaded into the Adaptor.
One example: 
To turn the robot 90° left it's necessary to do the Encoder calculations for movement manually:
```go
gopigo.EncoderTarget(false, true, 90/360.0/64)
gopigo.TurnLeft()
```
I cloud change the movement methods to:
```go
// 0 disables the encoder
func (g *GoPiGoAdaptor) TurnLeft(degrees int) 
```
Or:
```
// passing no value disables the encoder
func (g *GoPiGoAdaptor) TurnLeft(degrees ...int)
```
This would affect methods like `Forward` where it would be possible specify a distance in cm.

title: Simplify new adaptor/new driver function signatures
body:
This PR simplifies the new Adaptor and new Driver function signatures as discussed in https://github.com/hybridgroup/gobot/issues/307 

What is currently this:

``` go
e := edison.NewEdisonAdaptor("edison")
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "led", "13")
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "button", "5")
```

now becomes:

``` go
e := edison.NewAdaptor()
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "13")
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "5")
```

If you want a specific name, you would then just do this:

``` go
e := edison.NewAdaptor()
e.SetName("board")
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "13")
led.SetName("flashlight")
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "5")
button.SetName("on-switch")
```

In addition the `gpio` and `i2c` sub-packages are now located under `/drivers` instead of being lumped in with all of the `platforms` packages.

Lastly, official Gobot support for versions of Golang < 1.5 has been dropped.

title: Change new adaptor/new driver function signatures to not require name
body:
This is derived from an email conversation I had with @mattetti thanks Matt!

It started me thinking about the naming thing. Seems like a little more separation of concerns might be useful to better accommodate devs who want to use Gobot as library not the full framework.

Specifically, I think that devs who care about a specific name to be used by the API can easily define that themselves, and everyone else will be satisfied with an auto-generated name, or not care about the internal name.

So what is currently this:

``` go
e := edison.NewEdisonAdaptor("edison")
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "led", "13")
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "button", "5")
```

would become:

``` go
e := edison.NewAdaptor()
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "13")
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "5")
```

If you wanted a specific name, you would then just do this:

``` go
e := edison.NewAdaptor()
e.Name = "board"
led := gpio.NewLedDriver(e, "13")
led.Name = "flashlight"
button := gpio.NewButtonDriver(e, "5")
button.Name = "on-switch"
```

To reduce stuttering we should rename all single adaptors and drivers such as this:

``` go
ardrone.ArdroneAdaptor
ardrone.NewArdroneAdaptor()
```

to this:

``` go
ardrone.Adaptor
ardrone.NewAdaptor()
```

I think this will simplify most people use cases, however it would mean a breaking change to the new Adaptor and new Driver functions.

Feedback, please!

title: Fix the ServoConfig byte order
body:
This corrects the byte order according to the [servo](https://github.com/firmata/protocol/blob/master/servos.md) protocol specification. It describes the bytes to be sent as:

```
// minPulse and maxPulse are 14-bit unsigned integers
0  START_SYSEX          (0xF0)
1  SERVO_CONFIG         (0x70)
2  pin number           (0-127)
3  minPulse LSB         (0-6)
4  minPulse MSB         (0-13)
5  maxPulse LSB         (0-6)
6  maxPulse MSB         (7-13)
7  END_SYSEX            (0xF7)
```

While this seems to fix the Firmata client, issue #172 seems to be asking for this to be exposed in the FirmataAdapter. It would be easy enough to add to the adapter, and if that's wanted I can update the PR to include that.

title: Adding the initial NATS platform support
body:
This commit is to support NATS.io messaging protocol. This basic implementation supports the simplest use cases and follows directly the same implementation as the MQTT protocol. Parity is brought to bear between the two protocols. You can almost use them interchangeably except that the CLIENTID on the MQTT platform for GoBot uses a `string` while NATS uses an `int` for unique client. 

I intend to extend this code to add many more features from NATS. However, I wanted to at least get the platform docs, examples and happy-path use case implemented so that GoBotters (is that a thing?!?) could jump on using the NATS protocol for their projects. 

Finally, while I added some tests, once again I tried to meet the same type/number of tests that the MQTT platform added. This is weird to me because they added some tests which succeed only when the server is running and some that only succeed when the server is NOT running. I did meet both of these but don't really like this because there is no way to run the whole suite to success. I could fix this through mocking but with such little amount of code, I didn't want to expand the platform just for dependency injection and mocking - NOR did I want to add support for a mocking library and complicate the deployment process. I'm open to comments on this - I can work harder on the tests if needed.

title: Code cleanup, improve go report card.
Fix broken tests
body:
_Problem_

Since `errFunc` is a variable it's crucial to ensure its value is
properly set.

``` go
var errFunc = func(t *testing.T, message string) {
    t.Errorf(message)
}
```

but `TestAssert` and `TestRefute` happen to override it

``` go
errFunc = func(t *testing.T, message string) {
    err = message
}
```

without restoring the previous value, causing all the following tests to never
fail as, instead of calling `t.Errorf`, it just assigns `err` value

_Solution_

This commit refactors `Assert` and `Refute` to not use global `errFunc`
variable, but instead introduce a `TestFailer` interface to achieve
same results

title: Wiichuck driver doesn't work with the sysfs i2cDevice
body:
When using the Wiichuck driver with a Raspberry Pi or C.H.I.P. (through the sysfs i2cDevice implementation), the following error floods the screen -

```
2016/01/31 22:15:53 Event does not exist
2016/01/31 22:15:53 Event does not exist
...
...
```

Some findings -

There are 2 parts to this problem - a) what is the event that's triggering the specific "event does not exist" error? b) why is that event getting generated?

a) The Wiichuck driver only adds the C, Z and Joystick events, but not the Error event. In `wiichuck_driver.go` -

``` go
    w.AddEvent(Z)
    w.AddEvent(C)
    w.AddEvent(Joystick)
    return w
```

So whenever any kind of error is encountered (eg in I2cRead()) the above message gets generated. The fix for that is trivial. Just add `w.AddEvent(Error)` before returning.

b) The i2cDevice code in `sysfs/i2c_device.go` uses the I2C_SMBUS block transfer mode. It appears that the Wii nunchuk doesn't support it -

```
# i2cdump -y 0 0x52 s
Error: Adapter does not have SMBus block read capability
```

The thing to note here is that this only affects I2cRead() for the wiichuck. Although I2cWrite is also called, it is only called for writing 1 or 2 bytes and for those lengths, the code doesn't do I2C_SMBUS but instead writes directly on the file descriptor -

``` go
func (d *i2cDevice) Write(b []byte) (n int, err error) {
    if len(b) <= 2 {
        return d.file.Write(b)
    }
...
```

Looking at the relevant i2c header file in linux kernel source (http://lxr.free-electrons.com/source/include/uapi/linux/i2c-dev.h#L47) it appears that there is an ioctl command to get the functionality (I2C_FUNCS). So a possible way to fix this would be to first query the [functionality supported](http://lxr.free-electrons.com/source/include/uapi/linux/i2c.h#L83) by the specific adapter and then pick an appropriate transfer mode.

Previous code spawns ~1000 go-routines due to NewEvent in my test. Removing a
goroutine and making the loop of callbacks happen directly in Write with
a lock reduces this to ~12 in my test.

While I agree that explicit locks are not nearly as nice looking as implicitly locking channels, I think the gain in simpler stack traces (~1000 x a few lines gives a LONG trace!) is enough of a reason by itself to include this change. I see no performance penalty of interest (the amount of locks have not been reduced - every channel is a locked queue, and the time to loop over a slice that often has a count of 1 is negligible), but there might be a small performance gain overall, due to lower count of goroutines and active locks that the scheduler has to keep track of. That is, however, just a bold and unscientific claim.

title: gobot should not intercept os.Interrupt
body:
gobot should not attempt to "own" the main application, by making blocking code that starts messing with application-wide signal handlers. A more Go-style external API would be:

```
    gobot.Start()
    defer gobot.Stop() // This would then call the connection finalizers
```

This would let users decide on their own shutdown mechanisms, rather than have gobot try to own the main application.

My personal idea would be to actually just expose and use Start and Stop on each robot, which would effectively make gobot.Start and gobot.Stop mere convenience wrappers that just iterated them (which could either be killed completely or left behind for convenience). Does that idea sound bad?

title: Save ~1000 goroutines
body:
Previous code spawns ~1000 go-routines due to NewEvent in my test. Removing a
goroutine and making the loop of callbacks happen directly in Write with
a lock reduces this to ~12 in my test.

While I agree that explicit locks are not nearly as nice looking as implicitly locking channels, I think the gain in simpler stack traces (~1000 x a few lines gives a LONG trace!) is enough of a reason by itself to include this change. I see no performance penalty of interest (the amount of locks have not been reduced - every channel is a locked queue, and the time to loop over a slice that often has a count of 1 is negligible), but there might be a small performance gain overall, due to lower count of goroutines and active locks that the scheduler has to keep track of. That is, however, just a bold and unscientific claim.

title: PWM exported functions for Intel Edison
body:
To be able to properly use the PWM possibilities of the Edison, one needs to set the `period` and `duty cycle` to create a pulse at a given frequency:

```
If you want a 1.6kHz wave that is a 625 microsecond period or 626000 nanoseconds (assuming a 50% duty cycle).

echo -n "625000" > /sys/class/pwm/pwmchip0/pwm3/period
echo -n "312500" > /sys/class/pwm/pwmchip0/pwm3/duty_cycle
```

Unfortunately, right now, gobot developers don't have access to period and duty cycle, as a matter of fact, they have almost no access to anything pwm related and only `func (e *EdisonAdaptor) PwmWrite` seems exposed (and it does a lot of magic).

My suggestion is to export `pwmPin` and its methods so developers interested in going a bit lower level can have fun ;)

body:
As I stated in issue #84, packet sent to sphero gets a DID field, like 0x00, and 0x02, means the virtual device this packet is intended for.
So I change one of the parameters in the func craftPacket from fixed "0x02" to "did", so we can identify the DID when the request packet generated and sent.
func (s *SpheroDriver) craftPacket(body []uint8, did byte, cid byte) *packet {
249 packet := new(packet)
250 packet.body = body
251 dlen := len(packet.body) + 1
252 packet.header = []uint8{0xFF, 0xFF, did, cid, s.seq, uint8(dlen)}
253 packet.checksum = s.calculateChecksum(packet)
254 return packet

For example, if I want to get the power state of sphero, I have to send the packet to virtual device 0x00 like this:
func (s *SpheroDriver) GetPowerState() []uint8 {
189 return s.getSyncResponse(s.craftPacket([]uint8{}, 0x00, 0x20))
190 }

And for this change, I change each func which call the craftPacket.
I will try to submit more API implementation after this commit.
